intro: Silene glauca subsp. macrotheca, commonly known as the large-flowered catchfly, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Caryophyllaceae family and is characterized by its showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and woodland edges, and it has hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are borne on tall, slender stalks and are visited by various pollinators, including bees and flies. The subspecies is distinguished by its larger flower size compared to other members of the Silene glauca complex.
